content.title: Hawking Temperature Formula
content.summary: The Hawking temperature is the temperature at which a black hole emits thermal radiation due to quantum effects near the event horizon. It reveals deep connections between quantum mechanics, general relativity, and thermodynamics.

formula.latex: T_H = \frac{\hbar c^3}{8\pi G M k_B} = \frac{m_P}{8\pi M} T_P

steps: Uncertainty in momentum: Δp ~ ℏ/r_s ~ ℏc²/(2GM)
Characteristic energy: E ~ Δp × c ~ ℏc³/(2GM)
Temperature: k_B T ~ E, giving T ~ ℏc³/(GMk_B)
heuristic.note: Gives correct order of magnitude; factor of 8π from proper calculation

steps: Quantize scalar field on black hole background
Compare in and out vacuum states
Find thermal spectrum with temperature T_H

key_relationships.inverse_mass: T_H ∝ 1/M: smaller black holes are hotter
key_relationships.planck_scale: At M = m_P, temperature reaches T_P/8π

physical_interpretation.particle_creation: Virtual particle pairs near horizon: one falls in, one escapes
physical_interpretation.information_loss: Thermal radiation appears to lose information (paradox)
physical_interpretation.negative_heat_capacity: Losing energy makes BH hotter (unstable equilibrium)

theoretical: First prediction combining quantum mechanics and general relativity
Revealed black holes have thermodynamic properties
Led to black hole information paradox
significance.observational: Not yet detected due to extremely low temperatures of astrophysical BHs
